title: Can you connect an old DVD player to a new TV? - Quora

response.answer_text: I assume you mean to play DVDs. There are too many possibilities depending on your available outputs and inputs, and tolerance for relatively low-quality video. Put simply, most modern TVs still have either coaxial (screw-on single large cable) and/or composite (red/white/yellow RCA plugs at each end) inputs, and older, going-back-to-the-’70’s players of all types (VCR anybody?) ditto. Coax is lowest quality but simple, R/W/Y is better, but still low by what most of us consider acceptable. Going up in quality, you might have on both units composite (R/W for audio, R/Blue/Green for video RCA plugs), S-video (3/8″ dia. plug with small pins, short-lived tech and requires separate R/W audio cable-unlikely on the TV), digital, either orange RCA plug called coaxial digital, sometimes PCM or Bitstream, or optical digital, a small square plug, also known by an abbreviation I’ve forgotten, but something like Philips Sony Digital Interface, both also requiring R/W audio. In my case my VCR (R/W/Y), old DVD (R/W/R/B/G), and newer (but still 10-yr-old) DVD recorder (R/W/optical digital) are all connected to a switcher, which goes to one TV input (R/W/Optical digital). But since I usually play optical discs on my BluRay player through the HDMI input which upconverts (improves) picture quality to near-HD, perhaps your best solution is to buy a BluRay player for a hundred bucks or so, use the HDMI input (assuming your TV has one available), and one simple cable does it all. Hope this helps!

Yes, but you will probably need an adapter. A lot depends on what kind of output the DVD has. The best is R-G-B (component out).
